title: Gallic War 6 13 - Druids as judges - Set 1

content.question:
Illi rebus divinis intersunt, sacrificia publica ac privata procurant, religiones

interpretantur: ad hos magnus adulescentium numerus disciplinae causa concurrit,

magnoque hi sunt apud eos honore. Nam fere de omnibus controversiis publicis

privatisque constituunt et, si quod est admissum facinus, si caedes facta, si de

5hereditate, de finibus controversia est, idem decernunt, praemia poenasque

constituunt; si qui aut privatus aut populus eorum decreto non stetit, sacrificiis

interdicunt.

Bellum Gallicum 6. 13

Answer the following questions in English unless the question specifically asks you to write out Latin words. Number your answer to each question.

1. What is the case and use of religiones (line 1) ?

2. In lines 1-3 (Illi . . . honore), which two-word Latin phrase indicates that Druids are teachers?

3. Which two Latin verbs are connected by the conjunction et (line 4) ?

4. In this passage, which three Latin words summarize the kinds of judicial decisions the Druids preside over?

5. In lines 3-7 (Nam . . . interdicunt), which five Latin words can be translated “if there is a dispute over land”?

6. In lines 3-7 (Nam . . . interdicunt), (A) identify one perfect tense verb and (B) translate it in context.

7. In this passage, which three words identify what happens at the end of a case overseen by the Druids?

8. (A) Identify two genitives in this passage. (B) What is the use of each?

9. Briefly describe how Roman religious figures used their sacrificia to interpret the will of the gods. Answer in 1-2 complete sentences.
